paper_abstract: A memrsitor is a two-terminal electronic device whose conductance can be precisely modulated by charge or flux through it. In this paper, we present a class of memristor-based neural circuits comprising leaky integrate-and-fire (I & F) neurons and memristor-based learning synapses. Employing these neuron circuits and corresponding SPICE models, the properties of a two neurons network are shown to be similar to biology. During correlated spiking of the pre- and post-synaptic neurons, the strength of the synaptic connection increases. Conversely, it is diminished when the spiking is uncorrelated. This synaptic plasticity and associative learning is essential for performing useful computation and adaptation in large scale artificial neural networks. Finally, future circuit design and consideration are discussed with the memristor-based neural networks.
paper_title: Associative Learning of Integrate-and-Fire Neurons with Memristor-Based Synapses
